Web Scraping Tennis Abstract with Playwright

A concise guide to scraping JavaScript-rendered tennis data using modern Python tools
Tennis
Python
Web Scraping
Tutorial
Published

February 2, 2026

On this page

  • IntroductionTennis Abstract is one of the best resources for tennis statistics on the web. Created by Jeff Sackmann, it provides detailed match histories, serve statistics, and performance data for professional tennis players.The challenge: Tennis Abstract uses JavaScript to render its data tables. If you try scraping with requests + BeautifulSoup, you‚Äôll get an empty page because the content loads dynamically after the initial HTML.The solution: Playwright - a modern browser automation library that can:- Launch a real browser (headless or visible)- Wait for JavaScript to execute- Extract data from the fully-rendered pageIn this tutorial, we‚Äôll build a scraper to fetch player match histories and serve statistics, then visualize the data.> üìö Playwright Documentation>> Key resources to bookmark:>> - Getting Started - Installation and first steps> - Selectors Guide - How to find elements on a page> - Locators API - Modern, auto-waiting element selection> - Actionability & Waiting - Understanding when elements are ready> üìù Sync vs Async API>> Playwright offers both synchronous and asynchronous APIs. In Jupyter notebooks, we must use the async API because notebooks run inside an asyncio event loop. For standalone scripts, the sync API (sync_playwright) is simpler.
  • Setup
  • Understanding the Target Page
  • Building the Scraper
  • Debugging TipsWhen your scraper isn‚Äôt working as expected, Playwright provides several ways to debug:1. Run with visible browser - Set headless=False to watch the browser:pythonbrowser = await p.chromium.launch(headless=False, slow_mo=500) # slow_mo adds delay between actions2. Take screenshots - Capture the page state at any point:pythonawait page.screenshot(path="debug.png", full_page=True)3. Interactive debugging - Pause execution and inspect manually:pythonawait page.pause() # Opens Playwright Inspector4. Trace Viewer - Record a full trace for post-mortem debugging:pythoncontext = await browser.new_context()await context.tracing.start(screenshots=True, snapshots=True)# ... your scraping code ...await context.tracing.stop(path="trace.zip")# Open with: playwright show-trace trace.zip> üí° Modern Locator API>> The examples in this tutorial use query_selector() for simplicity, but Playwright‚Äôs modern Locator API provides auto-waiting and better debugging:>> python> # Modern approach using locators (auto-waits for elements)> table = page.locator("#recent-results")> rows = await table.locator("tr").all()>> # Locators can chain and filter> cells = await row.locator("td").all_inner_texts()>>> Locators automatically wait for elements to be actionable and provide better error messages.
  • Error Handling & RetriesProduction scrapers need robust error handling. Here‚Äôs a pattern with exponential backoff:
  • Example: Scraping Jannik Sinner‚Äôs Matches
  • Comparing Two Players
  • Visualizing First Serve Percentage

  • Rate Limiting & EthicsWhen scraping any website, be a good citizen:1. Rate limit your requests - Add delays between page loads (e.g., 2 seconds)2. Respect robots.txt - Check if scraping is allowed (robots.txt specification)3. Don‚Äôt overload servers - Scrape during off-peak hours for large jobs4. Credit the source - Tennis Abstract data is maintained by Jeff Sackmannpythonimport asyncioplayers = ["JannikSinner", "CarlosAlcaraz", "NovakDjokovic"]for player in players: data = await scrape_player_with_stats(player, player.split()[-1]) await asyncio.sleep(2) # Wait 2 seconds between requests> üìù Checking robots.txt Programmatically>> You can check robots.txt before scraping using Python‚Äôs built-in urllib.robotparser:>> python> from urllib.robotparser import RobotFileParser>> rp = RobotFileParser()> rp.set_url("https://www.tennisabstract.com/robots.txt")> rp.read()>> # Check if scraping a specific URL is allowed> url = "https://www.tennisabstract.com/cgi-bin/player.cgi?p=JannikSinner"> if rp.can_fetch("*", url):> print("Scraping allowed")> else:> print("Scraping disallowed by robots.txt")>>> Always check robots.txt before scraping a new site, and respect Crawl-delay directives if present.
  • Using the Sync API (for Scripts)
  • Conclusion

IntroductionTennis Abstract is one of the best resources for tennis statistics on the web. Created by Jeff Sackmann, it provides detailed match histories, serve statistics, and performance data for professional tennis players.The challenge: Tennis Abstract uses JavaScript to render its data tables. If you try scraping with requests + BeautifulSoup, you‚Äôll get an empty page because the content loads dynamically after the initial HTML.The solution: Playwright - a modern browser automation library that can:- Launch a real browser (headless or visible)- Wait for JavaScript to execute- Extract data from the fully-rendered pageIn this tutorial, we‚Äôll build a scraper to fetch player match histories and serve statistics, then visualize the data.> üìö Playwright Documentation>> Key resources to bookmark:>> - Getting Started - Installation and first steps> - Selectors Guide - How to find elements on a page> - Locators API - Modern, auto-waiting element selection> - Actionability & Waiting - Understanding when elements are ready> üìù Sync vs Async API>> Playwright offers both synchronous and asynchronous APIs. In Jupyter notebooks, we must use the async API because notebooks run inside an asyncio event loop. For standalone scripts, the sync API (sync_playwright) is simpler.

Setup

First, install the required packages:

pip install playwright pandas plotly
playwright install chromium

The second command downloads a Chromium browser for Playwright to control.

from playwright.async_api import async_playwright
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
from datetime import datetime
import asyncio
import re

Understanding the Target Page

Each player on Tennis Abstract has a page like: - ATP: https://www.tennisabstract.com/cgi-bin/player.cgi?p=JannikSinner - WTA: https://www.tennisabstract.com/cgi-bin/wplayer.cgi?p=IgaSwiatek

The recent matches table has the ID #recent-results and contains these columns:

Index Column Description
0 Date Match date (e.g., ‚Äú19-Jan-2026‚Äù)
1 Tournament Tournament name
2 Surface Hard, Clay, or Grass
3 Rd Round (F, SF, QF, R16, etc.)
4 Rk Player‚Äôs ranking at match time
5 vRk Opponent‚Äôs ranking
6 Result Who won (e.g., ‚ÄúSinner d. Djokovic‚Äù)
7 Score Match score
8 DR Delta ranking
9 A% Ace percentage
10 DF% Double fault percentage
11 1stIn First serve in percentage
12 1st% First serve points won
13 2nd% Second serve points won
14 BPSvd Break points saved
15 Time Match duration

Building the Scraper

Let‚Äôs build a scraper that captures both match results and serve statistics:

def parse_result(result_text: str, player_name: str) -> dict:    """Parse the result cell to extract win/loss and opponent info."""    if " d. " not in result_text:        return {"won": None, "opponent": None}        winner_part, loser_part = result_text.split(" d. ")        def extract_name(text):        text = re.sub(r'\(\d+\)', '', text)  # Remove seed        text = re.sub(r'\[.*?\]', '', text)  # Remove country        text = re.sub(r'\(WC\)|\(Q\)|\(LL\)', '', text)  # Remove entry type        return text.strip()        winner_name = extract_name(winner_part)    loser_name = extract_name(loser_part)    player_won = player_name.lower() in winner_name.lower()        return {        "won": player_won,        "opponent": loser_name if player_won else winner_name    }def parse_percentage(text: str) -> float:    """Parse percentage string like '65%' or '65' to float."""    try:        return float(text.replace('%', '').strip())    except (ValueError, AttributeError):        return Nonedef parse_date(date_str: str) -> datetime:    """Parse date string like '19-Jan-2026' to datetime."""    try:        return datetime.strptime(date_str.strip(), "%d-%b-%Y")    except ValueError:        return Noneasync def scrape_player_with_stats(player_url_name: str, player_last_name: str, tour: str = "atp") -> pd.DataFrame:    """    Scrape recent matches with serve statistics for a player.        Args:        player_url_name: Player name in URL format (e.g., "JannikSinner")        player_last_name: Player's last name for result parsing        tour: "atp" or "wta"        Returns:        DataFrame with match data and serve stats    """    prefix = "w" if tour == "wta" else ""    url = f"https://www.tennisabstract.com/cgi-bin/{prefix}player.cgi?p={player_url_name}"        async with async_playwright() as p:        browser = await p.chromium.launch(headless=True)        page = await browser.new_page()        await page.goto(url, wait_until="domcontentloaded")                # Wait for the table to be visible instead of using a fixed timeout        # This is more robust - it waits only as long as needed        await page.wait_for_selector("#recent-results", state="visible", timeout=10000)                table = await page.query_selector("#recent-results")        if not table:            print(f"Could not find table for {player_last_name}")            await browser.close()            return pd.DataFrame()                rows = await table.query_selector_all("tr")        rows = rows[1:]  # Skip header        matches = []                for row in rows:            cells = await row.query_selector_all("td")            cell_texts = [await cell.inner_text() for cell in cells]            cell_texts = [text.strip() for text in cell_texts]                        if len(cell_texts) >= 12:  # Need serve stats columns                result_info = parse_result(cell_texts[6], player_last_name)                                matches.append({                    "player": player_last_name,                    "date": parse_date(cell_texts[0]),                    "tournament": cell_texts[1],                    "surface": cell_texts[2],                    "round": cell_texts[3],                    "won": result_info["won"],                    "opponent": result_info["opponent"],                    "score": cell_texts[7],                    "ace_pct": parse_percentage(cell_texts[9]) if len(cell_texts) > 9 else None,                    "df_pct": parse_percentage(cell_texts[10]) if len(cell_texts) > 10 else None,                    "first_serve_pct": parse_percentage(cell_texts[11]) if len(cell_texts) > 11 else None,                    "first_serve_won_pct": parse_percentage(cell_texts[12]) if len(cell_texts) > 12 else None,                    "second_serve_won_pct": parse_percentage(cell_texts[13]) if len(cell_texts) > 13 else None,                })                await browser.close()        return pd.DataFrame(matches)

Debugging TipsWhen your scraper isn‚Äôt working as expected, Playwright provides several ways to debug:1. Run with visible browser - Set headless=False to watch the browser:pythonbrowser = await p.chromium.launch(headless=False, slow_mo=500) # slow_mo adds delay between actions2. Take screenshots - Capture the page state at any point:pythonawait page.screenshot(path="debug.png", full_page=True)3. Interactive debugging - Pause execution and inspect manually:pythonawait page.pause() # Opens Playwright Inspector4. Trace Viewer - Record a full trace for post-mortem debugging:pythoncontext = await browser.new_context()await context.tracing.start(screenshots=True, snapshots=True)# ... your scraping code ...await context.tracing.stop(path="trace.zip")# Open with: playwright show-trace trace.zip> üí° Modern Locator API>> The examples in this tutorial use query_selector() for simplicity, but Playwright‚Äôs modern Locator API provides auto-waiting and better debugging:>> python> # Modern approach using locators (auto-waits for elements)> table = page.locator("#recent-results")> rows = await table.locator("tr").all()>> # Locators can chain and filter> cells = await row.locator("td").all_inner_texts()>>> Locators automatically wait for elements to be actionable and provide better error messages.

Error Handling & RetriesProduction scrapers need robust error handling. Here‚Äôs a pattern with exponential backoff:

async def scrape_with_retry(player_url_name: str, player_last_name: str, tour: str = "atp",                             max_retries: int = 3) -> pd.DataFrame:    """    Scrape player data with retry logic and error handling.        Uses exponential backoff: waits 2s, then 4s, then 8s between retries.    """    for attempt in range(max_retries):        try:            async with async_playwright() as p:                browser = await p.chromium.launch(headless=True)                page = await browser.new_page()                                prefix = "w" if tour == "wta" else ""                url = f"https://www.tennisabstract.com/cgi-bin/{prefix}player.cgi?p={player_url_name}"                                # Navigate with timeout                response = await page.goto(url, wait_until="domcontentloaded", timeout=15000)                                # Check for HTTP errors                if response and response.status >= 400:                    raise Exception(f"HTTP {response.status} for {player_url_name}")                                # Wait for content with explicit timeout                try:                    await page.wait_for_selector("#recent-results", state="visible", timeout=10000)                except Exception:                    print(f"Table not found for {player_last_name} - player may not exist")                    await browser.close()                    return pd.DataFrame()                                # Extract data (simplified for this example)                table = await page.query_selector("#recent-results")                row_count = len(await table.query_selector_all("tr")) - 1  # Minus header                                await browser.close()                print(f"Successfully scraped {row_count} matches for {player_last_name}")                return pd.DataFrame({"player": [player_last_name], "matches_found": [row_count]})                        except Exception as e:            wait_time = 2 ** (attempt + 1)  # Exponential backoff: 2, 4, 8 seconds            print(f"Attempt {attempt + 1} failed for {player_last_name}: {e}")                        if attempt < max_retries - 1:                print(f"Retrying in {wait_time}s...")                await asyncio.sleep(wait_time)            else:                print(f"All {max_retries} attempts failed for {player_last_name}")                return pd.DataFrame()# Test the retry logicresult = await scrape_with_retry("JannikSinner", "Sinner")result

Example: Scraping Jannik Sinner‚Äôs Matches

Let‚Äôs test our scraper by fetching Sinner‚Äôs recent match history with serve stats:

sinner_matches = await scrape_player_with_stats("JannikSinner", "Sinner", tour="atp")

print(f"Found {len(sinner_matches)} matches for Sinner")
sinner_matches[["date", "tournament", "opponent", "won", "first_serve_pct", "ace_pct"]].head(10)

Comparing Two Players

Now let‚Äôs scrape data for both Sinner and Alcaraz to compare their serve statistics. We‚Äôll add a small delay between requests to be respectful to the server.

# Scrape Alcaraz (with rate limiting)
await asyncio.sleep(2)  # Be nice to the server
alcaraz_matches = await scrape_player_with_stats("CarlosAlcaraz", "Alcaraz", tour="atp")

print(f"Found {len(alcaraz_matches)} matches for Alcaraz")

# Combine the data
all_matches = pd.concat([sinner_matches, alcaraz_matches], ignore_index=True)
all_matches = all_matches.dropna(subset=["date", "first_serve_pct"])
all_matches = all_matches.sort_values("date")

print(f"\nTotal matches with serve data: {len(all_matches)}")
all_matches.groupby("player").size()
Found 20 matches for Alcaraz

Total matches with serve data: 41
player
Alcaraz    20
Sinner     21
dtype: int64

Visualizing First Serve Percentage

Let‚Äôs create an interactive plot comparing Sinner and Alcaraz‚Äôs first serve percentage over time:

# Create the comparison plot
fig = px.scatter(
    all_matches,
    x="date",
    y="first_serve_pct",
    color="player",
    hover_data=["tournament", "opponent", "won", "surface"],
    title="First Serve % Over Time: Sinner vs Alcaraz",
    labels={
        "date": "Date",
        "first_serve_pct": "First Serve %",
        "player": "Player"
    },
    color_discrete_map={"Sinner": "#e94560", "Alcaraz": "#4facfe"}
)

# Add trend lines
for player, color in [("Sinner", "#e94560"), ("Alcaraz", "#4facfe")]:
    player_data = all_matches[all_matches["player"] == player].copy()
    if len(player_data) > 1:
        # Rolling average for trend
        player_data = player_data.sort_values("date")
        player_data["rolling_avg"] = player_data["first_serve_pct"].rolling(window=5, min_periods=1).mean()
        
        fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(
            x=player_data["date"],
            y=player_data["rolling_avg"],
            mode="lines",
            name=f"{player} (5-match avg)",
            line=dict(color=color, width=2, dash="dash"),
            hoverinfo="skip"
        ))

fig.update_layout(
    height=500,
    hovermode="closest",
    legend=dict(orientation="h", yanchor="bottom", y=1.02, xanchor="center", x=0.5)
)

fig.show()

Summary Statistics

Let‚Äôs compare their average serve statistics:

# Calculate summary statistics
summary = all_matches.groupby("player").agg({
    "first_serve_pct": ["mean", "std", "min", "max"],
    "ace_pct": "mean",
    "df_pct": "mean",
    "won": "mean"
}).round(1)

summary.columns = ["1st Serve % (avg)", "1st Serve % (std)", "1st Serve % (min)", "1st Serve % (max)",
                   "Ace % (avg)", "DF % (avg)", "Win Rate"]
summary["Win Rate"] = (summary["Win Rate"] * 100).round(1)

print("Serve Statistics Comparison")
print("=" * 50)
summary
Serve Statistics Comparison
==================================================
1st Serve % (avg) 1st Serve % (std) 1st Serve % (min) 1st Serve % (max) Ace % (avg) DF % (avg) Win Rate
player
Alcaraz 66.4 4.6 57.8 76.8 6.5 2.2 80.0
Sinner 67.8 5.5 55.1 75.2 13.0 1.5 100.0

First Serve % by Surface

How does their first serve vary across different surfaces?

# Group by player and surface
surface_stats = all_matches.groupby(["player", "surface"]).agg({
    "first_serve_pct": "mean",
    "date": "count"
}).reset_index()
surface_stats.columns = ["player", "surface", "first_serve_pct", "matches"]

# Only show surfaces with enough matches
surface_stats = surface_stats[surface_stats["matches"] >= 3]

fig = px.bar(
    surface_stats,
    x="surface",
    y="first_serve_pct",
    color="player",
    barmode="group",
    title="Average First Serve % by Surface",
    labels={"first_serve_pct": "First Serve %", "surface": "Surface"},
    color_discrete_map={"Sinner": "#e94560", "Alcaraz": "#4facfe"},
    text="first_serve_pct"
)

fig.update_traces(texttemplate="%{text:.1f}%", textposition="outside")
fig.update_layout(height=400, yaxis_range=[50, 75])
fig.show()

Rate Limiting & EthicsWhen scraping any website, be a good citizen:1. Rate limit your requests - Add delays between page loads (e.g., 2 seconds)2. Respect robots.txt - Check if scraping is allowed (robots.txt specification)3. Don‚Äôt overload servers - Scrape during off-peak hours for large jobs4. Credit the source - Tennis Abstract data is maintained by Jeff Sackmannpythonimport asyncioplayers = ["JannikSinner", "CarlosAlcaraz", "NovakDjokovic"]for player in players: data = await scrape_player_with_stats(player, player.split()[-1]) await asyncio.sleep(2) # Wait 2 seconds between requests> üìù Checking robots.txt Programmatically>> You can check robots.txt before scraping using Python‚Äôs built-in urllib.robotparser:>> python> from urllib.robotparser import RobotFileParser>> rp = RobotFileParser()> rp.set_url("https://www.tennisabstract.com/robots.txt")> rp.read()>> # Check if scraping a specific URL is allowed> url = "https://www.tennisabstract.com/cgi-bin/player.cgi?p=JannikSinner"> if rp.can_fetch("*", url):> print("Scraping allowed")> else:> print("Scraping disallowed by robots.txt")>>> Always check robots.txt before scraping a new site, and respect Crawl-delay directives if present.

Using the Sync API (for Scripts)

If you‚Äôre writing a standalone Python script (not a notebook), you can use the simpler synchronous API:

from playwright.sync_api import sync_playwright

def scrape_player_with_stats(player_url_name: str, player_last_name: str, tour: str = "atp"):
    prefix = "w" if tour == "wta" else ""
    url = f"https://www.tennisabstract.com/cgi-bin/{prefix}player.cgi?p={player_url_name}"
    
    with sync_playwright() as p:
        browser = p.chromium.launch(headless=True)
        page = browser.new_page()
        page.goto(url, wait_until="domcontentloaded")
        page.wait_for_timeout(3000)
        
        # ... rest of scraping logic (without await)
        
        browser.close()

The sync API is cleaner for scripts, but won‚Äôt work inside Jupyter notebooks or other async contexts.

Conclusion

In this tutorial, we built a web scraper for Tennis Abstract using Playwright and used it to compare serve statistics between Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz. Key takeaways:

  • Playwright handles JavaScript-rendered content that traditional scraping tools can‚Äôt
  • Use the async API in notebooks, sync API in scripts
  • Wait for content to load before extracting data
  • Parse serve statistics for deeper analysis beyond win/loss records
  • Visualize trends with interactive Plotly charts
  • Be respectful - rate limit and credit your sources

For a more comprehensive scraper that handles multiple players and outputs CSV compatible with Jeff Sackmann‚Äôs data format, check out the full implementation at data/scrape_tennisabstract.py in this repository.

Data source: Tennis Abstract by Jeff Sackmann. Match data is made available under the CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license.
